dt: {bc}to grow prosperous especially at the expense of another

et: probably from Old Norse {it}batna{/it} to improve; akin to Old English {it}betera{/it} better
shortdef: to grow prosperous especially at the expense of another —usually used with on

dt: {bc}a piece of lumber used especially for flooring
{bc}a thin narrow strip of lumber used especially to seal or reinforce a joint
{bc}a strip, bar, or support resembling or used similarly to a batten (as in a sail)

et: alteration of Middle English {it}batent, bataunt{/it} finished board, from Anglo-French {it}*bataunt{/it}, from present participle of {it}batre{/it} to beat, from Latin {it}battuere{/it}
shortdef: a piece of lumber used especially for flooring
a thin narrow strip of lumber used especially to seal or reinforce a joint
a strip, bar, or support resembling or used similarly to a batten (as in a sail)

dt: {bc}to fasten with or as if with battens
{bc}to make one secure by or as if by battens
{bc}to prepare for a difficult or dangerous situation

shortdef: to fasten with or as if with battens —often used with down
to make one secure by or as if by battens

dt: {bc}to prepare for possible trouble or difficulty

dt.t: People are {it}battening down{/it} in preparation for a fierce storm.

dt: {bc}to tie, close, or cover (something) in order to prevent it from moving or becoming damaged

dt.t: Everything on the ship's deck was {it}battened down{/it}.

shortdef: to prepare for possible trouble or difficulty
to tie, close, or cover (something) in order to prevent it from moving or becoming damaged

dt: {bc}to live well or succeed by using (something or someone)

dt.t: He is someone who {it}battens on{/it} the generosity of others.

shortdef: to live well or succeed by using (something or someone)
